Description: Rim and upper body sherd of large Corinthian black-figured pottery alabastron; glaze fired brown; tongue pattern on top of lip; exterior: tongues at top of wall; below, black-figure decoration consisting of lion to right (head, open-mouthed and cross-hatched mane, with added red on ruff and added white dots between lines on neck remaining); probable filling ornament at left.
Curator's comments: For parallels, see an alabastron once in Leipzig (CVA Leipzig, Antikenmuseum der Karl Marx Universität i, pl. 25, no. 4829).
Bibliographic references: Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 303, no. 797)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 52-3, no. A7)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 219, no. 28)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.149) (Phase 1)
